attr.a:
Set of continuous functions $`f : X \rightarrow X`$ is bijective to set of continuous functions $`g : Y \rightarrow Y`$ because of the homeomorphism $`m`$:

```math
m:X \rightarrow Y
```

therefore $`f`$ and $`g`$ can be defined by each other. That means for any $`g`$ there exists $`f`$ such that:

```math
g(x) = m \cdot f \cdot m^{-1} (x)
```

![](assets/IMG_4A2EA45092AF-1.jpeg)

If $`m^{-1} (x)`$ is the fixed point of $`g`$, for there is always one because of the fixed-point property, then it becomes:

```math
\begin{aligned}
    g(x) &= m \cdot m^{-1} (x) \\
         &= x
\end{aligned}
```

Therefore if there's a fixed point for $`f`$, there's one for $`g`$ too.
attr.q: Prove that if the space $`(X,\mathcal{T})`$ has the fixed-point property and $`(Y, \mathcal{T}_1)`$ is a spae homeomorphic to $`(X,\mathcal{T})`$, then $`(Y,\mathcal{T}_1)`$ has the fixed-point property.
